dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcGIS 10.0.5.4400

enttyp.enttypd: Location point features and attribute fields for 5,192 geothermal wells in Oregon
enttyp.enttypds: Unpublished well records or reports, Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number.
attr.attrdefs: ESRI

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry.
attr.attrdefs: ESRI

attr.attrdef: An Observation URI is a unique identifier for this header record. This is the identifier that will be used to cross reference logs, samples, other observations to the well or borehole represented by this header. It is a pdf hyperlink that DOGAMI established to view information about each unique well. The hyperlinks for geothermal prospect wells and the geothermal wells connect directly to their permit files. The hyperlinks for low temperature wells connect directly to the Oregon Water Resources Department's water well database.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: A TG URI is a unique identifier for every temperature gradient well in the database. It is an excel hyperlink that DOGAMI established in order to view the temperature-depth information. The wells that have a unique TG URI entry have other non-temperature related well information in their Observation URI. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: A human derived name by which the well is known.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: An API number is a unique numeric indentifier assigned to a particular well. It was established by the American Petroleum Institute. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The Header URI is a unique hyperlink that DOGAMI established in order to view a summary of the basic well information, excluding the temperature gradient data. Not every well has this attribute provided.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The Other ID is an alternative name found to be associated with a particular well. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: This field gives an alternative name found to be associated with a particular well. Well type designation is as follows: The geothermal wells have a GW followed by a unique number. The geothermal prospect wells have a GP followed by a unique number. The low temperature wells have a 4 letter abbreviation of a county within Oregon followed by a unique number.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The operator is the name of the drilling company involved with the drilling of a particular well. Only the geothermal wells and the geothermal prospect wells have a known operator. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The spud date is the date that the drilling of a particular well began. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The ended drilling date is the day that the drilling of a particular well stopped. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The well type is a description of the purpose of the well. The purpose of the geothermal energy well is to extract fluid from the subsurface as a medium for transporting heat from subsurface heat reservoir for use. The purposed of the temperature well is to take a temperature reading but does not necessarily mean that a temperature gradient exists. The purpose of the monitoring well is to monitor some subsurface properties. The purpose of the water well is to extract water for use and they consist of low temperature wells. The purpose of the geotechnical well is to extract fluids for use and they consist of low temperature wells. The purpose of a temperature depth well is to document the temperature gradient of a specific well. These wells are specifically from temperature depth logs and do not match any other type of well with supplemental well information.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: well has been drilled, abandoned and then plugged

attr.attrdef: Drilling status of well. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Depatment of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Date on which the reported status is valid. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Name of the field in which the well is located. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Departmenr of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: County in which the well is located.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: State in which the well is located. In this database, the wells are always located in the state of Oregon.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: The meridian that township and range are in reference to
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Township part of the location. It consists of a 3 digit number (padded with a zero as the first numner) followed by a N or S to signify specific direction.
attr.attrdefs: Public Land Survey System (PLSS)

attr.attrdef: Range part of the location. It consists of a 3 digit number (padded with a zero as the first numner) followed by a W or E to signify specific direction.
attr.attrdefs: Public Land Survey System (PLSS)
Public Land Survey System (PLSS)
attr.attrdef: Section part of the location. Each range is split into 36 sections and this indicates in which section the well is located.

The letters that follow the subdivision of township, range, and section system. The letters indicate where in the section the well is located. Each section is split into 4 parts- N,S,W,E. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Public Land Survey System (PLSS)

attr.attrdef: Latitude in decimal degree or Y coordinate for center point of each point
attr.attrdefs: ESRI geographic projection function

attr.attrdef: Longitude in decimal degree or X coordinate for center point of each point
attr.attrdefs: ESRI geographic projection function

attr.attrdef: SRS identifiers refer to the many different projected and geographic coordinate system identifiers available through ESRI. They offer information for specifying the data used for latitude and longitude locations.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: WGS84. Horizontal component of 3D system. Used by the GPS satellite navigation system and for NATO military geodetic surveying.

attr.attrdef: text statement on the uncertainty of location coordinates. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Driller total depth is the total depth in feet drilled. It is the total depth of the well. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: Kelly Bushing. depth measurements in reference to this rotary drill adapter.
Ground Level. depth measurements in reference to the ground level.
Drilling rig Floor. depth measurements in reference to the drilling rig floor.

attr.attrdef: Depth Reference is the physical point at which the measurment of the depth starts. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: term to indicate shape of drilled well
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: straight up and down, no horizontal drilling
edom.edomvds: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: true vertical depth of the well drilled is the absolute vertical distance between the datum and the point in the wellbore. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Unit in which depth is measured = Feet
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Elevation KB is the elevation of the depth reference point, KB, or kelly bushing. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Elevation DF is the elevation of the depth reference point, DF, or the drilling rig floor. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Elevation GL is the elevation of the depth reference point, GL, or the ground level. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Bit Diameter Collar is the bit diameter at the well origin. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Bit Diameter TD is the bit diameter at the bottom of the well. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Diameter Units is the units in which the bit diameters were measured = inches. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Maximum Recorded Temperature is the highest temperature recorded for a particular well. Not all wells have temperature data.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Temperature Units is the units in which the temperature is measured = Fahrenheit. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oeregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Measurment Procedure is the text description of how the temperature measurment was made. consists of logs, equipment and instrument names. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Depth of Measurement is the depth at which the temperature measurment was taken (if known). Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oreogn Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Measurement Source is the source of the temperature measurment, usually a well log. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Casing Logger is the deepest cased depth in the well encountered during the log run. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Drilling Fluid is the fluid used in the process of drilling. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Salinity is the concentration of ions in the fluid, if that well information is known, which was rare. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Density of mud. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: pH is the measure of acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Viscosity is the resistance to flow due to the internal friction caused by molecular cohesion of the fluid. It is the ratio of shear stress to shear rate in the fluid. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Deparmtment of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Fluid Loss is the measured loss of fluid. Not every well has this attribute.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvds: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: geothermal prospect well that also has temperature gradient data
edom.edomvds: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries
Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: geothermal well that also has temperature gradient data
edom.edomvds: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries
Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

edom.edomvd: low temperature well that also has temperature gradient data
edom.edomvds: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: Well Label is a way to sort and indentify the different types of wells in this database, specifically to be able to identity all the wells that have temperature gradient data.
attr.attrdefs: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

attr.attrdef: U.S. Geological Survey 1:100,000-scale (100K) topographic map in Oregon where the geothermal prospect well is located
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: U.S. Geological Survey 1:24,000-scale (24K) topographic map in Oregon where the geothermal prospect well is located
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

overview.eaover: Many field names in the attribute table have been truncated--ESRI's database limitations. An aliases for them has been provided which match the original Borehole Data template's column header.

cntperp.cntorg: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

citeinfo.origin: Clark A. Niewendorp, Kelley W. Rabjohns, Shane H. Brodie
citeinfo.title: GTILO-2_Well_database

pubinfo.publish: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

descript.abstract: This GIS shapfile holds 5,192 points representing geothermal prospect wells, geothermal wells, low temperature wells and temperature gradient wells in Oregon. The data in the Geothermal Well database and accompaning GIS shapfile called GTILO-2_Geothermalspring_database are part of the Geothermal Information Layer for Oregon, Release 2 (GTILO-Release 2), the Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries' (DOGAMI) geospatial database system that stores and manages Oregon's geothermal resource information.
descript.purpose: This Geothermal Well spatial database was developed to illustrate those areas in Oregon that either have been investigated for geothermal resource potential or show potential for a geothermal resource.
descript.supplinf:
The database contains records for four well types:
1. A geothermal prospect well is defined as any well drilled as a geophysical test well, seismic shot hole, mineral exploration drilling, core drilling or temperature gradient test well, less than 2,000 feet in depth, and drilled in prospecting for geothermal resources.
2. A geothermal well includes any excavation made for producing geothermal resources and any geothermal reinjection well.
3. Low Temperature Wells are defined as those wells within which there is water having temperatures greater than 65°F (18.3°C) or a minimum temperature of slightly less than 10°C above mean annual air temperature, and wells that are at least 60 ft (18.3 m) deep. When the temperature of the water was acquired and by which means are entirely unknown. Additionally, there is no universally accepted definition for a low temperature well, in terms of the temperature of the water that it contains or depth that it was drilled. The intent is to include wells that appear to contain water with temperatures higher than the mean temperature of groundwater in the area.
It should be understood that the low temperature well information was extracted from the Oregon Water Resources Division (OWRD) water well database which contains over 500,000 records for domestic/irrigation/other wells. At least 138,000 of these records reported water temperature data, but as few as 5,500 records listed water temperature data greater than 20°C (68°F). About half of these well records were culled for various data quality reasons leaving approximately 1,500 to 2,500 wells with possibly useful water temperature information. For example, all wells that are known to have been dug by hand or drilled by auger were purposefully omitted.
As a quality assurrance measure and a step to match records from GTILO-Release 1, temperature data for over 600 well records were checked against the Oregon Water Resources Department's original well logs. Also, many missing flow/rate attributes from GTILO-Release 1 were populated with this well log data. Additionally, the authors have also included 12 wells that are shallower than 60 ft (18.3 m) deep and above 90°F (32°C), and 40 wells from GTILO-Release 1 which do not include depth information. Duplicate WELL_IDs and points sometimes occur when a well was deepened or if the well log was altered in some way.
4. A temperature gradient well is defined as follows: a well from which temperature gradient data were obtained in order to determine the rate of increase in temperature per unit of depth in the Earth. Temperature gradients vary widely over the earth, sometimes increasing dramatically which would indicate additional geothermal activity within the Earth. A temperature gradient is a physical quantity that is expressed in units of degrees per unit length.
The Geothermal Well database is subject to change as new data are obtained, therefore updates to the database are expected. Please be aware that errors are possible because of data retrevial efforts. However, so far as possible care has been taken to mitigate these issues but the attribute table for GTILO-2 may contain errors, duplications, and omissions. Therefore, we cannot guarantee that the data are complete or accurate.

idinfo.accconst: None. Restrictions and legal prerequisites for using the data set after use is granted. These include any access constraints applied to assure the protection of privacy or intellectual property, and any special restrictions or limitations on using the data set.
idinfo.useconst:
Free access to data used in GTILO-Release 2 can be obtain at http://repository.usgin.org/collection. The data contained in GTILO-Release 2 are provided "as-is" without warranty of any kind, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. The user assumes all responsibility for the accuracy and suitability of this data set for a specific application or use with other data. In no event will the Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries be liable for any damages, including lost profits, lost savings, or other incidental or consequential damages arising from the use of or inability to use this data set.
These data are the result of integrating well logs, unpublished and published geothermal reports and maps, the accuracy of which varies according to the original source(s). Likewise its accuracy, particularly data resolution/scale(s), varies or is entirely unknown.
Acknowledgment of the Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries would be appreciated in products derived from this compiled data. Also, please add an acknowlegment for the U.S. Department of Energy (US DoE) and the Arizona Geological Survey, see Data Set Credit.
If the user has modified the data in any way, they are obliged to describe the types of modifications they have performed. User specifically agrees not to misrepresent this data set, nor to imply that changes they made were approved by the Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries. The Geothermal Well Database is not intended for site-specific investigations.
idinfo.datacred:
Clark A. Niewendorp (Prinicpal Investigator), Kelley W. Rabjohns, and Shane H. Brodie
To construct the database, DOGAMI used a grant awarded as a sub-proposal from the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) through the U.S. Department of Energy (US DoE) Geothermal Technologies Program. US DoE awarded funding to AZGS for the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, Public Law 111-5, US DoE Number: DE-FOA-0000109, Topic Area 3: Geothermal Data Development, Collection, and Maintenance.
The Arizona Geological Survey developed the database template: BoreholeTemperatureObservation1.0(1).xls that was used to record the well data.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7600) ; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000

theme.themekt: NASA/Global Change Master Directory (GCMD) Earth Science Keywords. Version 6.0.0.0.0

place.placekt: NASA/Global Change Master Directory (GCMD) Earth Science Keywords. Version 6.0.0.0.0
place.placekey: Continent > North America > United States of America > Oregon

browse.browsed: Overview of geothermal features (e.g. warm and hot springs), geothermal exploration wells (geothermal prospect and geothermal wells), and other wells that contain geothermally heated water

attracc.attraccr: The accuracy of this data is dependent on (1) detail level (e.g. location information) of the source material and (2) interpretation procedures for capturing that source. Field checking of the data was not performed.

dataqual.logic: Care was taken so that no duplicate features exist. Point data are represented by a single set of coordinate pairs. Because the data are from multiple sources, terminology varies and similar characteristics may be described differently.
dataqual.complete: Spatial data are presented in the form of points representing four types of geothermal wells and the coverage is statewide. All low temperature well attributes were captured from their reference source. Not all fields are attributed.

horizpa.horizpar: The method of digitization of the geothermal well locations involved heads-up digitization on the computer screen by using a computer mouse to scribe the feature. The following steps were taken to check those wells that had a high uncertainty relative to their location: 1) matching the well location description from cadastral location information found in well records to a U.S. Geological Survey Digital Raster Graphic (DRG) of 1:24,000-scale quadrangle, 2) inspecting 2005 Digital Orthophoto Quarter-Quadrangles (DOQQs) in the area for evidence of a well distrubance, and 3) examining tax-lot map information. The accuracy of the plot depends on a number of different types of errors: geodetic, machine, cartographic, and random errors. Not least of which are the errors related to the source material's level of detail and the interpretation procedures for capturing that source. A latitude/longitude was obtained after adjusting the wells location based on which step was used.

cntinfo.hours: 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Mon through Fri (Pacific Time)

procstep.procdesc: Well data were entered into an Excel spreadsheet called the BoreholeTemperatureObservation1.0(1).xls template. This template was developed by the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) for incorporation into the U.S. Geoscience Information Network and the National Geothermal Data System. We modified the template so it could be exported to ArcGIS environment, e.g. removing unnecessary header roles. A point coverage was generated unprojected (WGS 84).

cntperp.cntorg: Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries

cntinfo.hours: 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Mon through Fri (Pacific Time)

procstep.procdesc: Attributes were added to Field columns using the Intersect Point Tool provided by Hawth Analysis Tools, Version 3.27.

distinfo.resdesc: No warranty, expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data described and/or contained herein, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty regarding the utility of the data on any computer system or GIS computer program. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. The Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of these data. This information may be updated without notification.

stdorder.ordering: Contact The Nature of the Northwest Information Center by e-mail, phone, or letter explaining what products are needed.
stdorder.turnarnd: Order usually processed the same day received; mailed first class

distinfo.custom: Contact The Nature of the Northwest Information Center by e-mail, phone, or letter explaining what products are needed.
distinfo.techpreq: In order to view this dataset, mapping software is required (e.g. ESRI ArcView, MapInfo Pro, or other commercial or freeware GIS program). If you do not have access to any of the software mentioned, ESRI provides a free map viewer called ArcExplorer, which you can download over the Internet.
